{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3717651,"name":"Emil","username":"GronkBaby","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/ba8739/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-08-18T05:59:51.946Z","cooked":"

Hey everyone!
I tried making a PCB for the CANBus. But I only want to use one PCB that gets rotated (so I don’t need four different ones). Here is my current schematic (I’m using 8 so I can also give power to the CANcoders).

Screenshot 2025-08-18 at 08.53.171440×1018 63.4 KB

One of the problems I’m facing is that when the PCB gets rotated, the Yellow and Green switch places, if you will. Here’s a diagram illustrating my point.

Screenshot 2025-08-18 at 08.57.301420×776 114 KB

Is this fine that they switched? Like are the yellow and green line coming out of the motor significant, or are they there just to demonstrate that there are two different lines? Will I get an issue if I plug the green line from the CANBus into the yellow line of a device? If yes, what is the fix?

Any insights would be greatly appreciated

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2025-08-21T15:48:46.313Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":229,"reads":454,"readers_count":453,"score":1330.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":505408,"topic_slug":"trying-to-design-only-one-pcb-for-swerve-canbus","display_username":"Emil","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64351,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/trying-to-design-only-one-pcb-for-swerve-canbus/505408/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3717662,"name":"Tauseef Afraz","username":"TFM110","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tfm110/{size}/197758_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-18T06:29:18.219Z","cooked":"

It seems like you are making your own CANnect. If you are interested, the schematics are available on our Documentation!

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2025-08-18T06:29:18.219Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":402,"readers_count":401,"score":175.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":505408,"topic_slug":"trying-to-design-only-one-pcb-for-swerve-canbus","display_username":"Tauseef Afraz","primary_group_name":"Swyft-Robotics","flair_name":"FUN","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/3/5/3523e759b0af37a7757142a8b2aa79b31f1a47c4.png","flair_bg_color":"","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":60,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://swyftrobotics.com/products/swyft-cannect-wiring-system","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"SWYFT CANnect Wiring System – SWYFT Robotics","clicks":150},{"url":"https://docs.swyftrobotics.com/electronics/swyft-cannect","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"SWYFT CANnect | SWYFT Robotics Documentation","clicks":20}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":39084,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC5431AM | FRC5790M| FUN | SWYFT"},"post_url":"/t/trying-to-design-only-one-pcb-for-swerve-canbus/505408/2","custom_user_title":"FRC5431AM | FRC5790M| FUN | SWYFT","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3717664,"name":"wyatt","username":"stormsj28","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/a3d4f5/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-08-18T06:29:59.575Z","cooked":"

You will get an error, to my understanding one lin is high which is the line being sent from rio and one is low which is the receiving, not sure if that’s correct but that’s how it makes sense to me

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2025-08-18T06:29:59.575Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":394,"readers_count":393,"score":103.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":505408,"topic_slug":"trying-to-design-only-one-pcb-for-swerve-canbus","display_username":"wyatt","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":76247,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3218 CAD"},"post_url":"/t/trying-to-design-only-one-pcb-for-swerve-canbus/505408/3","custom_user_title":"3218 CAD","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3717666,"name":"wyatt","username":"stormsj28","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/a3d4f5/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-08-18T06:39:00.718Z","cooked":"

Switching where the outputs are for the rj45 might work?

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2025-08-18T06:39:00.718Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":377,"readers_count":376,"score":90.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":505408,"topic_slug":"trying-to-design-only-one-pcb-for-swerve-canbus","display_username":"wyatt","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":76247,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3218 CAD"},"post_url":"/t/trying-to-design-only-one-pcb-for-swerve-canbus/505408/4","custom_user_title":"3218 CAD","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3717667,"name":"bobbysq","username":"bobbysq","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bobbysq/{size}/195893_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-18T06:43:09.788Z","cooked":"
GronkBaby:

Is this fine that they switched? Like are the yellow and green line coming out of the motor significant, or are they there just to demonstrate that there are two different lines?

The two lines can not be switched. The simple explanation is that they carry two parts of the same signal, and switching them will bring the whole bus down as they attempt to transmit an inverted signal the rest of the bus can’t understand.

However, I’m not sure this will actually be an issue with your design, as long as you’re using standard CAT5 cables. They share the same pinout on both ends, so pin 1 will map to pin 1 on the next board. I would just be sure to look at the pinout and make sure you’re using sets of twisted pairs within the cable to transmit the signals.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2025-08-18T06:43:09.788Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":365,"readers_count":364,"score":103.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":505408,"topic_slug":"trying-to-design-only-one-pcb-for-swerve-canbus","display_username":"bobbysq","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28014,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"he/him"},"post_url":"/t/trying-to-design-only-one-pcb-for-swerve-canbus/505408/5","custom_user_title":"he/him","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3717701,"name":"Jim Sokoloff","username":"sokoloff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sokoloff/{size}/231724_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-18T11:43:02.349Z","cooked":"

I don’t fully understand the problem with rotating that you’re trying to avoid but, except for the space, “PCB footprints are free”, so I wouldn’t be afraid to place 4 (or more) RJ45 footprints and only populate two of them on any given board. That might give you the flexibility to achieve whatever rotation dependent reusability you’re seeking.

(We treat all of our swerve modules as physically indistinguishable when not installed on the bot, so we would have the same PCB on each module.)

For U1 and R1, because so few of these boards on a swerve unit will ever have the bus terminated there, I’d be more inclined to just create the R1 pad and “do not populate” it. If you’re doing PCBA from JLCPCB, that’ll save you $0.45 per U1 and $3 for 1 fewer extended part. If you’re doing the assembly yourself, it’s zero seconds to DNP R1.

Plus, it’s less likely that a U1 will get set (intentionally & misguided or accidentally) to on.

Alternatively, if you’re doing PCBA, populate R1 and change U1 to a two pin 0.1" header that is DNP. You could then on a few select boards populate a two-pin 0.1" header and then use a shorting jumper (like the old hard drives or a CMOS-clear jumper on a motherboard) for the rare cases where you want R1 in the circuit.

Edit to add: I’d also change the U1 designator to SW1 (or J1 if you’re using the header solution).

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2025-08-18T11:53:38.741Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":314,"readers_count":313,"score":157.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":505408,"topic_slug":"trying-to-design-only-one-pcb-for-swerve-canbus","display_username":"Jim Sokoloff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66298,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"97 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/trying-to-design-only-one-pcb-for-swerve-canbus/505408/6","custom_user_title":"97 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3717745,"name":"Emil","username":"GronkBaby","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/ba8739/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-08-18T13:31:59.681Z","cooked":"

What do you mean by " create the R1 pad and ‘do not populate it’ "?
Why does me doing the assembly vs. JLCPCB assembling it for me change whether I should use a header or not?

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2025-08-18T13:31:59.681Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":257,"readers_count":256,"score":81.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":505408,"topic_slug":"trying-to-design-only-one-pcb-for-swerve-canbus","display_username":"Emil","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":66298,"username":"sokoloff","name":"Jim Sokoloff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sokoloff/{size}/231724_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64351,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/trying-to-design-only-one-pcb-for-swerve-canbus/505408/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3717786,"name":"Kevin Forbes","username":"TheOtherGuy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/theotherguy/{size}/160832_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-18T14:17:36.150Z","cooked":"

DNP (do not populate) is a common way to make “variants” of a board. The example here is you would drop down two pads in parallel on the layout and only populate one for a given variant (“left hand” vs “right hand”, for example, if you are making these for an SDS Mk4n). That might be a resistor in the above example, perhaps one that is a 0 Ohm jumper.

It wouldn’t matter who makes it, just know that DNP may require more communication with the board house and is usually reflected in the bill of materials. And the jumper idea is a nice alternative that avoids the variant complication. KiCad doesn’t yet support them natively, I don’t think, though most EDA packages do.

All that said, if you’re using RJ45 connectors and Ethernet cables, just use the same pin numbering on both sides and don’t use crossover cables. I don’t know what connectors you’re using for the devices, but they should be the same pin-wise as well.

It’s generally very bad to short two wires of any multiconductor signal - for CAN, that’s a hard short that kills the bus, though transceivers will prevent further damage. With other signals you may not be so lucky.

Edit: I should add, there’s nothing wrong with your original schematic and rotation concept.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2025-08-18T14:19:55.689Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":248,"readers_count":247,"score":124.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":505408,"topic_slug":"trying-to-design-only-one-pcb-for-swerve-canbus","display_username":"Kevin Forbes","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":64351,"username":"GronkBaby","name":"Emil","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/ba8739/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6761,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Coach, 1540 & 1844 "},"post_url":"/t/trying-to-design-only-one-pcb-for-swerve-canbus/505408/8","custom_user_title":"Coach, 1540 & 1844 ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3717872,"name":"Brendan Simons, 5406","username":"nuclearnerd","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuclearnerd/{size}/7324_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-18T16:28:34.316Z","cooked":"

If you are only using 4 leads out of the ethernet cable, would it make sense to use use telephone cable / RJ11 jacks instead? The wire would be a lot smaller.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2025-08-18T16:28:34.316Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":208,"readers_count":207,"score":81.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":505408,"topic_slug":"trying-to-design-only-one-pcb-for-swerve-canbus","display_username":"Brendan Simons, 5406","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.digikey.com/en/products/detail/coolgear/CM-170101RBSTK/21576575","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":4}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22221,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/trying-to-design-only-one-pcb-for-swerve-canbus/505408/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3717962,"name":"Jim Sokoloff","username":"sokoloff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sokoloff/{size}/231724_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-18T18:04:02.910Z","cooked":"
GronkBaby:

Why does me doing the assembly vs. JLCPCB assembling it for me change whether I should use a header or not?

TheOtherGuy (both meanings) covered DNP pretty well. For JLCPCB, you can manage DNPs pretty easily (and for something like the header that’s a through-hole part, economy assembly doesn’t support it anyway).

The reason I suggested always having JLCPCB (or any other assembly house) always populate the resistor is that the cost for a surface mount resistor plus two pads worth of assembly charges is almost certainly under $0.02 and maybe right around $0.01, so you might as well just have them always do it and save the work later. On the other hand, if you’re assembling the boards and less than 5% of them will ever need on-board termination, I’m lazy enough to not populate those resistors until/unless needed.

GronkBaby:

What do you mean by " create the R1 pad and ‘do not populate it’ "?

Mechanism for a DNP resistor for assembly: put R1 in the schematic, assign the right footprint, put R1 on the PCB and route traces to it. You can then either remove R1 from the BOM or leave R1 in the BOM as a customer part with the part number “DNP”

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2025-08-18T18:04:02.910Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":215,"readers_count":214,"score":83.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":505408,"topic_slug":"trying-to-design-only-one-pcb-for-swerve-canbus","display_username":"Jim Sokoloff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66298,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"97 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/trying-to-design-only-one-pcb-for-swerve-canbus/505408/10","custom_user_title":"97 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3718115,"name":"Kevin Forbes","username":"TheOtherGuy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/theotherguy/{size}/160832_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-18T23:46:43.773Z","cooked":"

It’s tempting, and would likely work okay, but there are a couple advantages to ethernet cables. They have twisted pairs which increases immunity to EMI, an important feature in close proximity to large switching electromagnets like motors. The CAN bus characteristic impedance should be 120 Ohms. Telephone cables don’t usually have a controlled impedance - I estimated the cable you linked is around 140 Ohms which is decent, while ethernet cables are designed to be 100 Ohms. Neither should be problematic especially as the frequency is low relative to other high speed signals in the hundreds of MHz, but other RJ11 cables may not be that close. More importantly, the mechanical construction includes a robust jacket and internal plastic stiffener, which helps maintain a reliable connection on our (easily and frequently abused) robots.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2025-08-18T23:46:43.773Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":174,"readers_count":173,"score":84.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":505408,"topic_slug":"trying-to-design-only-one-pcb-for-swerve-canbus","display_username":"Kevin Forbes","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.analog.com/en/resources/technical-articles/use-a-twist-and-other-popular-wires-to-reduce-emirfi.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Use a Twist and Other Popular Wires to Reduce EMI/RFI | Analog Devices","clicks":1},{"url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Characteristic_impedance#Practical_examples","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Characteristic impedance - Just FYI, this isn’t how CAN works.

CAN bus uses a differential signal, meaning the HIGH/LOW values are not relative to some shared ground but relative to each other.

1296×900 31.5 KB

By taking the difference between the voltages on the two wires, it carries a digital 1 or 0.

The advantage of this is electro-magnetic interference resilience. If an EMI source (like a motor or radio) induces a voltage on the bus, it should induce it in both wires equally. So when the two voltages are subtracted from each other, the induced voltage cancels out and the signal is unchanged.

USB and ethernet and several other serial communication methods use differential signaling for the same reasons.

Something else that helps minimizethe EMI is that the strength of a magnetic field is proportional to the inverse of the distance. Doubling the distance will reduce the magnetic field strength by a factor of 8. Often, making sure the signal wires are in a separate bundle from the power wires will be sufficient.

Something else that helps minimize EMI is to make the power wires and signal wires cross each other at roughly 90 degrees to minimize the coupling efficiency. Running them parallel increases the coupling

philso:

Doubling the distance will reduce the magnetic field strength by a factor of 8.

For a point magnetic source.

For near-field cross-talk between parallel wire runs, I’m pretty sure it’s only by a factor of X when distance increases by a factor of X.

Progress! And help needed.

Screenshot 2025-08-26 at 20.14.111110×1008 84.4 KB

I am worried about the 90 degree forks in the CAN line for the devices. Will this be an issue for the CANFD for the swerve drivetrain I plan to run?

Screenshot 2025-08-26 at 20.16.051406×396 62.7 KB

I looked at the schematic for the CANnect, and they seem to also do a 90 degree turn without issue (although the schematic could be 100% different from the actual layout), so I’m not sure… Any advice? Any feedback or anything else something can see wrong?

If you’re wondering why I chose this weird layout, it’s because I want the connectors to always be on the outside even when I rotate it 90 degrees so they are close to the motors. If you look, you will see that the PCB is (almost) symmetric about the y = -x curve

Like always, any help y’all can provide is VERY appreciated

CAN is a fairly slow protocol.
